NAME: ENGLISH_FREQUENCY_LOG
NOTE: This value is based on log10(FREQcount+1) and has four-digit precision. Calculating the log frequency on the raw frequencies is the most straightforward transformation, because it allows one to give words that are not in the corpus a value of 0. One can easily lose 5% of the variance explained by taking log(frequency per million # 1), because, in this case, one is not making much of a distinction between words with low frequencies. Similarly, adding values lower than 1 (e.g., #1E#10) is dangerous, because one may end up with a big gap between the words in oneÕs corpus and words for which one does not have a frequency measure (which will get a log value of #10). In addition, if one uses log(frequency per million), one will have negative values for words with a frequency lower than 1 per million, and one will have to enter negative values for missing words. The downside of using log10(FREQcount # 1) is that there is no intuitive relationship between Lg10WF and SUBTLWF (frequency per million).

The first digit in the semkey indicates the broad semantic category to which it belongs, as described above, where «1» is used for «Body Parts», «2» is used for «Animals (and Animal Verbs)», and so on. NAME: TARGET_CONCEPTS
NOTE: Concepts that are derived from or semantically extended from the source concepts, often marked in complex expressions (e.g. “bark” being marked with morphemes from “skin”). The original concept pairs were taken from Urban ([2011](:bib:Urban2011)).

NAME: SOURCE_CONCEPTS
NOTE: Concepts that serve as the likely origin of a semantic extension, based on morphologically complex expressions (e.g. “tree skin” for “bark”) or directionality in derivation across languages. The original concept pairs were taken from Urban ([2011](:bib:Urban2011)).

NAME: LINKED_CONCEPTS
NOTE: Semantically related concepts that co-occur with the focal concept in polysemous forms across languages, indicating potential for semantic overlap or extension but without necessarily implying directionality of change. The original concept pairs were taken from Urban ([2011](:bib:Urban2011)).

NAME: TARGET_CONCEPTS
NOTE: Concepts that are derived from or semantically extended from the source concepts, often marked in complex expressions.

NAME: LINKED_CONCEPTS
NOTE: Semantically related concepts that co-occur with the focal concept in polysemous forms across languages, indicating potential for semantic overlap or extension but without necessarily implying directionality of change.

NAME: SHIFTS
NOTE: This variable captures two types of linguistic changes: derivational shifts involving morphological word formation, and polysemy shifts reflecting semantic expansion where words acquire related new meanings.

NAME: DOMAIN
NOTE: The broad semantic category or field that the concept belongs to, like nature, social life, emotions, or technology, helping to classify its general area of meaning.

NAME: ALIAS
NOTE: Alternative names, labels, or synonyms that are used to refer to the same concept, reflecting variation across dialects, registers, or historical stages.

NAME: DEFINITION
NOTE: A precise description capturing the essential meaning of a concept, explaining what it represents or denotes.

NAME: FAMILY_COUNT
NOTE: Number of distinct language families that include this concept.

NAME: LANGUAGE_COUNT
NOTE: Number of individual languages where the given concept appears.

NAME: VARIETY_COUNT
NOTE: Number of language varieties or dialects representing this concept.

NAME: LINKED_CONCEPTS
NOTE: Information about related concepts linked to the main concept. For each linked concept, the number of full variables (FullVars, i.e. fully mapped variables), the number of languages with full variables (FullLngs), and the number of language families with full variables (FullFams) is reported. It also includes counts of overlapping variables (OverlapVars), overlapping languages (OverlapLngs), and overlapping language families (OverlapFams) between the linked concepts and the main concept.

NAME: TARGET_CONCEPTS
NOTE: Concepts that are derived from or semantically extended from the source concepts, often resulting in more complex expressions. For each target concept, the number of variables exhibiting affixation (AffixVars), the number of languages with affixation data (AffixLngs), and the number of language families represented (AffixFams) are given.

NAME: ENGLISH_STABILITY_JUDGMENT_MEAN
NOTE: The mean correlation between individual and group ratings for each word (after removing outliers), indicating how consistently different raters judged the same word, though the rater sample varied across words.

NAME: ENGLISH_VISUAL_MEAN
NOTE: The mean rating on a 6-point scale (0= not at all, 3 = somewhat, 6 = very much) for how much a noun is considered something "you can easily see", to what degree a verb is "an action or activity in which you see something", or an adjective describes the property of "how something looks". “Not Applicable” responses to nonsensical queries were  0.

NAME: ENGLISH_BRIGHTNESS_MEAN

NAME: ENGLISH_PATTERN_MEAN

NAME: ENGLISH_BODY_MEAN

NAME: ENGLISH_TEMPERATURE_MEAN
NOTE: The mean rating on a 6-point scale (0 = not at all, 3 = somewhat, 6 = very much) for how extreme the temperature of a concept is, based on two separate queries about hot and cold attributes (the maximum rating of the two was used). For the HOT query, the mean rating was given for how much a noun is considered "hot to the touch", to what degree a verb is associated with "touching or feeling something hot", or an adjective describes the property of "a hot quality to the touch". For the COLD query, the mean rating was given for how much a noun is considered "cold to the touch", to what degree a verb is associated with "touching or feeling something cold", or an adjective describes the property of "a cold quality to the touch". No information is provided on whether these queries were given in separate questionnaires or together in one. “Not Applicable” responses to nonsensical queries were later converted into 0.

NAME: ENGLISH_TEXTURE_MEAN
NOTE: The mean rating on a 6-point scale (0 = not at all, 3 = somewhat, 6 = very much) for how extreme the tactile texture of a concept is, based on two separate queries about smooth and rough attributes (the maximum rating of the two was used). For the SMOOTH query, the mean rating was given for how much a noun is considered "having a smooth texture to the touch", to what degree a verb is associated with "touching or feeling something smooth", or an adjective describes the property of "a smooth quality to the touch". For the ROUGH query, the mean rating was given for how much a noun is considered "having a rough texture to the touch", to what degree a verb is associated with "touching or feeling something rough", or an adjective describes the property of "a rough quality to the touch". NAME: ENGLISH_FREQUENCY
NOTE: Orthographic frequency of a word in the Westbury Lab USENET Corpus [(Shaoul & Westbury 2013)](:bib:Shaoul2013).

NAME: ENGLISH_FREQUENCY_LOG
NOTE: Log-transformed orthographic frequency of a word in the Westbury Lab USENET Corpus [(Shaoul & Westbury 2013)](:bib:Shaoul2013).

NAME: ENGLISH_IMAGEABILITY_MEAN
NOTE: Mean imageability rating (how easily a word evokes a mental image) on a 7-point scale, based on a number of published norms [(Bird et al. 2001](:bib:Bird2001); [Clark & Paivio 2004](:bib:Clark2004); [Cortese & Khanna 2008](:bib:Cortese2008); [Wilson 1988)](:bib:Wilson1988).

NAME: ENGLISH_ONTOLOGICAL_TYPE
NOTE: The general ontological type of the word. “Property” for adjectives, “thing” for nouns; verbs are divided between “action” or “state”.

NAME: SEMANTIC_CATEGORY
NOTE: The broad semantic category of the concept, such as abstract action, abstract entity, abstract property, artifact, event, living object, mental entity, mental state, natural object, physical action, physical property, or physical state.

NAME: SEMANTIC_SUBCATEGORY
NOTE: The more specific semantic subcategory of the concept, such as abstract action, abstract construct, animal, animal part, auditory property, body action, body part, body state, building part, cognitive entity, cognitive property, creative action, distant object, document, electronic device, emotion, emotional property, food, furniture, general event, geological entity, group, human, instrument, locative action, mental action, mental state, miscellaneous action, multimodal property, perceptual action, perceptual state, physical action, place, plant, social action, social construct, social event, social property, somatosensory property, sound, spatial property, temporal property, time period, tool, vehicle, visual property, or weather event.

NAME: KMEANS28_CATEGORY
NOTE: Semantic categories automatically generated from a k-means clustering of the ratings, including Abstract and social actions, Animals, Beneficial abstract entities, Body parts, Causal entities, Festive social events, Human types, Ingestive events and actions, Large bright objects, Locative change acts, Loud vehicles, Musical instruments, Negative actions and properties, Negative emotion entities, Negative human roles, Negative natural events, Neutral abstract entities, Neutral human roles, Non-social places, Nonverbal sound events, Plants and foods, Positive emotion entities, Quiet vehicles, Sensory properties, Social places, Time concepts, Tools and furniture, and Verbal social events.

NAME: ENGLISH_AOA_MEAN
NOTE: The mean rating of age of acquisition (AoA) on a 7-point scale. The mean rating for each item was mutiplied by 100, resulting in a value betwwen 100 and 700 depicted here. Participants were asked to circle actual age bands (for example 3– 4, 5–6). Their answers were later converted to a 7-point scale (1 = ages zero to two, 2 = ages three to four, 3 = ages five to six, 4 = ages seven to eight, 5 = ages nine to ten, 6 = ages eleven to twelve, 7 = ages thirteen and above).

NAME: ENGLISH_IMAGEABILITY_MEAN
NOTE: The mean rating of imageability ("the ease with which a word gives rise to a sensory mental image") on a 7-point scale (1 = least imageable, 7 = most imageable). The mean rating for each item was mutiplied by 100, resulting in a value betwwen 100 and 700 depicted here.

NAME: ENGLISH_AOA_MEAN_MRC
NOTE: The mean rating of age of acquisition (AoA) on a 7-point scale (1 = ages zero to two, 2 = ages three to four, 3 = ages five to six, 4 = ages seven to eight, 5 = ages nine to ten, 6 = ages eleven to twelve, 7 = ages thirteen and above) as given in the MRC Psycholinguistic database [(Coltheart 1981)](:bib:Coltheart1981). The mean rating for each item was mutiplied by 100, resulting in a value betwwen 100 and 700 depicted here.

NAME: ENGLISH_IMAGEABILITY_MEAN_MRC
NOTE: The mean rating of imageability ("the ease with which a word gives rise to a sensory mental image") on a 7-point scale (1 = least imageable, 7 = most imageable) as given in the MRC Psycholinguistic database [(Coltheart 1981)](:bib:Coltheart1981). The mean rating for each item was mutiplied by 100, resulting in a value betwwen 100 and 700 depicted here.

NAME: ENGLISH_FREQUENCY_LOG_CELEX
NOTE: The logarithmic frequency of combined written and spoken count divided by total word count in the CELEX Database ([Baayen et al. 1996)](:bib:Baayen1996).
